g.text: shows the effects of particulate respirators on cardiopulmonary indicators after
levels. We observed a significant reduction in
resting SBP (−5.3 mmHg [95% CI, −9.3 mmHg, −1.2 mmHg]), MAP (−2.9 mmHg [95%
Effects of Particulate Respirator Use on Cardiopulmonary Function
Kernel density estimation of personal exposure to PM
periods with and without particulate respirators after accounting for respirator fitting performance (n = 21). Two
smoothing lines for the distribution of PM
exposure levels with and without particulate respirators were derived
Changes in cardiopulmonary indicators during the experimental period compared with the control
In the model, we controlled for age (years), weight (kg), height (cm), regular alcohol drinking (yes or no),
antihypertensive medication use (0 for no and 1 for yes), PM
CI = confidence interval, SBP = systolic blood pressure, DBP = diastolic blood pressure, MAP = mean arterial
pressure, PP = pulse pressure, HR = heart rate, FEV
= forced expiratory flow at 25%–75% of the FVC, HRV = heart
rate variability, SDNN = the standard deviation of normal-to-normal intervals, rMSSD = square root of the mean
squared differences of successive NN intervals, HF = high frequency (normalized), LF = low frequency (normalized),
LF/HF = the ratio of LF to HF, 8-OHdG = 8-hydroxy-2
